column1: The first European explorers to visit the Westchester area were Giovanni da Verrazzano in 1524 and Henry Hudson in 1609. Dutch settlers began arriving in the 1620s

column3: created by an act of the New York General Assembly in 1683. At the time it included present-day Bronx County
column4: and abutted then-Dutchess County to the north. By 1775
column5: Westchester was the richest and most populous county in the colony of New York. Although the Revolutionary War devastated the county
column6: recovery after the war was rapid. In 1788
column7: five years after the end of the war
column8: the county was divided into 20 towns. In 1798

column3: the Croton Aqueduct is considered one of the great engineering achievements of the 19th century. In the 1840s
column4: the first railroads were built in Westchester
column5: and included the New York and Harlem Railroad
column6: the Hudson River Railroad
column7: and the New York and New Haven Railroad. The railroads often determined the growth of a town
column8: and the population shifted from Northern to Southern Westchester. By 1860

column1: Westchester County is divided into six primary drainage basins or watersheds: the Upper and Lower Long Island Sound; and the Bronx
column2: Upper Hudson
column3: Lower Hudson
column4: and Croton River basins. Within these primary drainage basins are approximately 60 smaller basins
column5: or subwatersheds. The principal streams draining the southern part of the county include Beaver Swamp Brook

column7: Bronx River
column8: Hutchinson River
column12: Stephenson Brook and Tibbetts Brook. The primary streams draining the central part of the county include Byram River
column16: Pocantico River and Silvermine River. The principal streams draining the northern part of the county include Dickey Brook
column22: and Titicus River. The county contains several major reservoirs; The Croton system and the Kensico Reservoir are important components of the New York City water supply system. The system is a series of interconnected reservoirs and lakes in northern Westchester and Putnam Counties that provide 10% of New York City's water under normal conditions and up to 30% in times of drought. The components of the system include the New Croton Reservoir
column26: and the Muscoot Reservoir. Other major reservoirs are the Kensico and Byram Lake Reservoir
column27: while there are a number of smaller reservoirs throughout the county.

column1: The climate of Westchester County is primarily a humid subtropical climate (Koppen Cfa)
column2: with higher elevations bordering on a humid continental climate. Winters are cold
column3: wet
column4: and occasionally snowy throughout the county
column5: with more snow inland in higher elevations. Summers are hot inland but cooler towards the coast
column6: with somewhat of a relative dryness in the early part of summer. Precipitation is plentiful and in some elevated areas reaches over 50 inches. Snowfall is more common in Westchester than in New York City
column7: with the exception of the southeast of the county where snowfall is often between 20 and 25 inches. In January
column8: inland areas have a low of 21-26°F and a high of 34-37 °F while coastal areas have a low of 27-30 °F and a high of 38-41 °F. In the summer
column9: this effect is much milder. Coastal areas (Mamaroneck
column12: Port Chester) have highs of 81-83 °F and lows of 68-73 °F
column13: while inland highs will be 84-87 °F and lows will be 65-70 °F. Winds can be heavy

Tech Valley is a marketing name for the eastern part of New York State
column2: including the Hudson Valley and the Capital District. The term originated in 1998 to promote the Greater Albany metropolitan area as a competitor to regions such as Silicon Valley and Boston. It has since grown to represent the counties in New York between IBM's Westchester County plants in the south and the Canada–U.S. border to the north.

column1: Westchester County generally leans toward the political left. It last voted for the Republican nominee for president in 1988.

column2: Westchester County was a classic "Yankee Republican" county. It supported Republican presidential candidates in all but two elections from 1896 to 1988. However
column3: it swung Democratic in the early 1990s—much like other New York City suburbs. In the most recent national elections
column4: Westchester voters tended to be far more Democratic than the national average. In fact
column5: Westchester
column6: after New York City and Albany County
column7: has produced the biggest margins for statewide Democrats in recent years. Democratic voters are mainly concentrated in the more populated southern and central parts of the county. More than 63 percent of Westchester County voters voted for Barack Obama in the 2008 presidential race
column8: the seventh-highest percentage of any New York county.
